turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Nice view, huh?

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Breathtaking.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: What was God thinking when he built this place?

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: If we don't get out of here soon we can ask him in person.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Gabe!  Are you alright?

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: No, not really.  Throw down a rope.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Can you see light?

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Up ahead.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Gabe are you alright?

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: For the record, whenever you hear me sliding out of control, I'm never alright.  When I secure the line, come on up.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: No luck?

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Next time, date only basketball players.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: She's a lyin' bitch!!

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Get it!

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: They'll kill him!  He has no idea!

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: We gotta get out and fire a flare.  It's the only chance!

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: We might be able to go that way.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Forget it.  If that charge goes off before we can reach it, this whole damn crevice will slam shut on us.  This way.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Pull it apart!

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Start pulling it apart!  We're climbing down on it.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: This rope is sixty years old!

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: These old ropes can hold 900 lbs., each strand 300.  I'm 190, you're about 135 -- it just may hold.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Never

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Never, what?!

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: I've never weighed 135 lbs.!

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Helluva time for vanity!

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Frank!  No, Frank!  Frank!

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Jess, c'mon...

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Gabe!

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Hold on!  Hold on!  Reach up!

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Reach up!  Do it!

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Don't let me fall!

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Do it, goddammit!

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Thanks for holding on.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: We were going together before I ever let go of you.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: I'm holding you to that.  Gabe, what about Frank?

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: I don't know.  I don't know.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Crockett River is where the last of the money fell.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: If we go along the northern ridge, we can get there first.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: There's no "we".  There's a me. All I have to do is make it along the north wall to Bitker Ladder. What you're doing is going back down to the station to get help. And don't put on that mad face.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Forget it.  You're in no shape to climb alone. I stayed with you this far, and you didn't drop me, so I owe you. C'mon, let's go.  Hurry up, time is money.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: "Time is money" -- please.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: My heart can't take much more of this.  Look, if we climb down from here, it'll take two hours to get back to the station.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: That's exactly what I want you to do.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: What about you?

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: What do you think?  Maybe I could reach the ledge without falling. No, forget it.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Oh, good. For a minute I thought you'd lost your mind.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: But maybe with a good start I can hit those hand-holds.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Hand-holds?!  I can barely see them.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: We don't have time to argue about it!

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Are you crazy?  Has the altitude shrunk your brain, Gabe?

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Take the rope.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: I won't do it.  No way.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Take the rope.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Enough's enough.  How could anybody in their right mind... then again, you never were in your right mind.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Wrap it around that rock twice.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: I'm going to wrap it around your throat!

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: An' if I miss, dig in and try your best to slow the fall.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Forget it!  I refuse!

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Fine, it shouldn't bother your conscience.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Don't lay any guilt on me. Suicide's a personal thing, best done alone.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Just kidding.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Gabe?  Wait 'til I get over there.  Tie the rope so I can come across.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Can't do it.  Now go back and get help!

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: What about you?!

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: RUN, DAMMIT!!

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: The "old mouth to mouth" resuscitation routine.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: There's a lot more where that came from.  You're not leaving again?

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: And miss all of this peace and quiet?  Never, right Hal?

turns.speaker: KYNETTE
turns.text: Look here, the mountain man. You're Walker, right?

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Good memory.  You must be great with numbers.

turns.speaker: KYNETTE
turns.text: Your mouth's writing a check your ass can't cash, but if ya wanna buy some life, bring me the money.

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: I burned it.

turns.speaker: KYNETTE
turns.text: What the fuck you mean you burned it?

turns.speaker: GABE
turns.text: Never could save a thing.

turns.speaker: KYNETTE
turns.text: Now you get burned.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Where's the helicopter?

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: What the hell's going on?

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: The faster you find the bags, the bigger you boys' finder's fee will be.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: Right, all the bullets we can eat.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: He'll freeze.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Ryan, get a rope, I want the man on a leash, too.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: What's he doing?

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: The best he can since you gave him nothing.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Talk.  No tricks, no codes, no messages.  You haven't found us. It was a fake call.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: Jessie, I reached the top of the Tower.  So far, no sign of anyone.  Looks like a phoney call. Over.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Mr. Travers is not the athletic type, he needs something more direct.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: The only faster way up is the East Face and it's smooth as glass.  Maybe a dozen guys in the world could do it in good weather, only a psycho would try it in a storm.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Souvenirs?  No, wrong answer. Looks like your friend plans on hanging around, that possible?

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: No, he's gone.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: No, he's close, and he's using our money to keep you alive. Nobody's worth that much on the open market.  Except you, the loyal one.  Didn't I tell you to warm the place up?

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: It's up there, on the Tower.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: How far?

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: For Christ's sake, they're kids.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: We're not animals, but don't force us to be.  Walk over.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: You son of a bitch!  You said you wouldn't kill him!

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Sue me.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: Murdering, motherfucker...

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Kill a few people, they call you a murderer.  When you kill millions, you're called a conqueror.  Go figure.  Move on Tucker, time is short.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: You said there was a way across.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: There is.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: He never hurt anybody.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: I'm touched.  Kristel, check the chopper, let's go.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Travers, you're not running things.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: When he finds the money, you're as dead as me.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Tucker, you know where the money is-- I want it.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: Qualen, go fuck yourself.  The game's over--you lost.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: No, the goddamn game's not over! It's never over when you're playing against a team that doesn't care if they win or lose-- how do you negotiate with someone like that?!

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: Yeah...

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Anyone else following?

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: What's your names?

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: Tucker and Walker.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Tucker and Walker, we've lost three bags.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Have her come up.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: The down drafts would wipe her out.  It's the only chopper.  If it goes, you got no ride out.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: On top of the peak.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: It looks like a winding route.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: He asked you, how far?!  I think you've been taking the scenic route.  How far from here?

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: Half a day.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Then where the fuck is!

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: There.  You blind?

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: Rescue One -- please be advised Ranger Walker is making advances toward my girlfriend that are liable to get his ass kicked right into space, over.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Copy.  Hal, tell Gabe he only makes advances <u>to me</u> or else he'll be walking down four thousand feet, and sleeping outside.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Go after her.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: Hold on, baby, he'll get you.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Got to be Comb Bluff.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: Acknowledge.  Winds are too strong to get a chopper up there, Are you near any natural shelter? Over.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: You and Frank get the tents, thermal clothing, and medical supplies together.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Who's going with you?

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: You're looking at him.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Where's the rest of the team?

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: Bob and Rick are in Denver.  I gotta get up there as fast as possible.  Frank, get me a load of flares.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: You gotta be kidding me!  Do you want me to fly up after you? Over.

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: <u>Negative</u>.  The winds are too high.  I'm going to ride out the storm here.  I'll take shelter in the Douglas Exhibition Shaft. Over and out.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Oh, my God!

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: Climb, Gabe, climb!

turns.speaker: HAL
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: JESSIE
turns.text: Then it's a deal.

turns.speaker: MATHESON
turns.text: I don't know about totally.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Who the hell ever is.  This is the most protected shipment we've got-- and the most useless. These bills aren't even <u>in</u> circulation; the one thousand dollar bills we're transporting are only used for international banking exchange.

turns.speaker: MATHESON
turns.text: Do you always transport through the air?

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: What the hell are you doing--

turns.speaker: MATHESON
turns.text: Now I have jurisdiction!  I said get your weapons.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: These are highly trained agents overreacting without just cause.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Calm down...give the gun to me. You're out of control, son.

turns.speaker: MATHESON
turns.text: What the hell are you waiting for, goddammit!  Don't you see what he's doing!  He's hijacking the shipment!

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Travers!  Hurry it up.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: On my way.  The cases are hooked up and ready.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Why didn't you send the money over?

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Somehow I didn't think you'd wait for me if I'd sent it first.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: What's the delay?

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Let's move your ass in there!!

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Kill me?  Christ we're partners in this!

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Were.  Give me the tracking monitor!

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Why?  What are you going to do?!

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: The monitor! I never ask twice.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Don't use my name!

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Ask the questions.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: You're both with the mountain rescue team?

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Where's the third one, Travers?

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: There, what's that place?

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Get off my back, Qualen!

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: I haven't even got on it yet.  Let's go, time to fetch.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Don't give him anything.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: We agree on something.  And for insurance, take his coat.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: I don't trust him.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Kill him when he gets down.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Bring down the money or your friend's dead!

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: We can't and he knows it.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Man against nature, right Travers.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: What about it?

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Down there you buy a life, up here you earn it or die.  How's your health?

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: This way.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Then go fetch.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: He's alive!

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: He can't be far away.  Find him. Go!

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Jessie?  Looks like your friend found company.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: We're down to a few hours before the whole world shows up here.  Where's the next one?

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Good, Travers.  It might catch on, like shooting skeet.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: You dumb bastard, you waited too long.  If he made it back, this place would have been covered with police in a few hours.  The way we're moving, it's going to be anyway.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: This is insane.  The hell with the money.  You radio in for that chopper, understand!

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Hey, you dealt us this hand, we're playing it all the way. Move.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Is it set?

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Primed to go off right over his head, officer.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Why the hell are we wasting time here?!

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Insurance against him finding that last case ahead of us.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: What's the code, Travers?

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: I told you, 50,000 possible keycode combinations, in fifteen second intervals.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Give me the fucking code!

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: You got what we need?

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: No, that son-of-a-bitch Walker is alive.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: No names, this is an open line!

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: I don't give a shit, Qualen!  I had to be insane to ever tie up with a low-life, piece of shit like you.  They beat us.  A couple of fuckin' hick mountain boys beat the man no law agency ever could.

turns.speaker: QUALEN
turns.text: Get off the radio!

turns.speaker: WRIGHT
turns.text: Rich...

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Good morning, Walt.

turns.speaker: WRIGHT
turns.text: I'd like to have a word with you. This is Agent Matheson, FBI.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: Richard Travers.

turns.speaker: WRIGHT
turns.text: Matheson has been transferred from the Denver office to Frisco. As a professional courtesy between offices, I was asked if he could hitch a ride.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: We've got a full crew, but we can squeeze one more, right.

turns.speaker: WRIGHT
turns.text: Appreciate it.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: You're the boss.  Let's head out to the tarmac.  Matheson, have you been totally briefed?

turns.speaker: WRIGHT
turns.text: Mostly.  Armored cars can be hijacked.  Trains can be derailed.  But nobody can get to us in flight.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: I haven't lost a bill in eighteen years, don't jinx me, Walt.

turns.speaker: WRIGHT
turns.text: I think Treasury personnel are the most superstitious people in the federal government.

turns.speaker: TRAVERS
turns.text: We should be.  Everybody wants what we have.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Hello Lucy, had a busy night? Puts money in machine.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: We've been working hard too. Takes glass.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Pardon me. Luce. He raises glass to breast, pulls red handle between her legs. Milk spurts into glass. Dim joins the others. Alex looks at a party of tourists.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: There was some sophistos from the TV studios around the corner, laughing an govoreeting. The Devotchka was smecking away, and not caring about the wicked world one bit. Then the disc on the stereo twanged off and out, and in the short silence before the next one came on, she suddenly came with a burst of singing, and it was like for a moment, O my brothers, some great bird had flown into the milkbar and I felt all the malenky little hairs on my plott standing endwise, athe shivers crawling up like slow malenky lizards and then down again. Because I knew what she sang. It was a bit from the glorious 9th, by Ludwig van. Dim makes a lip-trump followed by a dog howl, followed by two fingers pronging twice in the air, followed by a clowny guffaw. Alex brings his stick down smartly on Dim's legs.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: What did you do that for?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: For being a bastard with no manners and not a dook of an idea how to comport yourself publicwise, O my Brother.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: I don't like you should do what you done. And I'm not your brother no more and wouldn't want to be.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Watch that... Do watch that, O Dim, if to continue to be on live thou dost wish.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Yarbles, great bolshy yarblockos to you I'll meet you with chain, or nozh or britva, any time, not having you aiming tolchocks at me reasonless. It stands to reason, I won't have it.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: A nozh scrap any time you say. Dim weakens.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Doobidoob... a bit tired maybe, everybody is. A long night for growing malchicks... best not to say more. Bedways is rigthways now, so best we go homeways and get a bit of spatchka. Right, right.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: He are here! He have arrived! Hooray!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Welly, welly, welly, welly, welly, welly, well. To what do I owe the extreme pleasure of this surprising visit? Georgie rises.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Sorry about the pain. Using the gulliver to much like, eh? Giving orders and disciplining and that perhaps, eh? You sure the pain's gone? You sure you'll not be happier back up in bed.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Lets get things nice and sparkling clear. This sarcasm, if I may call it such, does not become you, O my brothers. As I am your droog and leader, I am entitled to know what goes on, eh? Now then, Dim, what does that great big horsy gape of a grin portend?

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: One minoota, droogie. Dim smashes Alex in the face with a full milk bottle. He goes down. The others run away, laughing.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You bastards... bastards.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Well, well, well, well, well, well, well, if it isn't little Alex. Long time no viddy, droog. How goes? Surprised are you?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Impossible... I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Come on, Alex. Come for walkies. Hahahahaha.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Come, come, my little droogies. I just don't get this at all. The old days are dead and gone. For what I did in the past I've been punished.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Been punished, yeah?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I've been cured.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Been cured, yeah, that was read out to us. The Inspector read all that out to us. He said it was a very good way.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I just don't get this all. It was them that went for me, brothers. You're not on their side and can't be. You can't be Dim. It was someone we fillied with back in the old days... Trying to get his own malenky bit of revenge after all this time. You remember, Dim?

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Long time, is right. I don't remember them days too horrorshow. Don't call me Dim no more, either. Officer, call me.

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: Dear, dear, dear. Whatever happened to you, my boy? Mr. Alexander, now confined to a wheelchair, pushes himself away from his desk, and rolls up to Julian. The water drips off Alex's clothes. They look at each other.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: The police... The horrible ghastly Police. They beat me up, sir. The Police beat me up, sir. Mr. Alexander stares at him. It becomes apparent he is insane.

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: I know who you are! Isn't it your picture in the newspapers? Didn't I see you this morning on the video? Are you not the poor victim of this horrible new technique?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, sir, that's exactly who I am, sir... and what I am... a victim, sir. Mr. Alexander becomes frenzied as the speech progresses.

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: Then, by God, you have been sent here by providence. Tortured in prison, then thrown out to be tortured by the Police. My heart goes out to you, poor, poor boy. Oh, you are not the first to come here in distress. The Police are fond of bringing their victims to the outskirts of this village. But it is providential that you, who are also another kind of victim, should come here. But you're cold and shivering. Julian, draw a bath for this young man.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Good evening, sir.

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: Good evening.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: It was very kind of you to leave this out for me, sir. There was no-one around when I finished my bath, so I started. I hope that's alright, sir.

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: Of course. Food alright?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Great, sir. Great.

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: Try the wine!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Thank you very much, sir. Cheers Suddenly the thought occurs to Alex that the wine may be drugged or poisoned.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Won't you join me, sir?

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: No, my health doesn't allow it.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: And you, sir?

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: I'm so pleased you appreciate good wine. Have another glass!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: My wife... Alex freezes.

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: ... used to do everything for me and leave me to my writing.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Your wife, sir? Has she gone away?

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: No. She's dead!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I'm sorry to hear about that, sir. His face contorted in rage.

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: She was very badly raped, you see. We were assaulted by a gang of vicious young hooligans in this house, in this very room you're sitting in now. I was left a helpless cripple. The doctors said it was Pneumonia, because it happened some months later during the 'flu epidemic. The doctors told me it was Pneumonia, but I knew what it was. A victim of the modern age, poor, poor girl. Suddenly his mood changes. He wheels right up to Alex.

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: And now you, another victim of the modern age. But you can be helped. I phoned some friends while you were having a bath.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Phoned some friends, sir?

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes. They want to help.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Help me, sir?

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: Help you.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Who are they, sir?

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: They're very, very important people and they're interested in you. Bell rings. Julian rises,

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: Julian. This will be these people now. Alex gets up.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Look, sir. I'm sorry to have troubled you. I think I ought to be going, sir. Julian bars the way.

turns.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
turns.text: No, no my boy. No trouble at all. Alex slowly sits.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Excuse me, missus, can you please help? There's been a terrible accident. Can I please use your telephone for an ambulance?

turns.speaker: CATLADY
turns.text: I'm frightfully sorry. There is a telephone in the Public House about a mile down the road. I suggest you use that.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: But, missus, this is an emergency. It's a matter of life and death. Me friend's lying in the middle of the road bleeding to death.

turns.speaker: CATLADY
turns.text: I... I'm very sorry, but I never open. I'm very sorry but I never open the door to strangers after dark.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Very well, madam. I suppose you can't be blamed for being suspicious with so many scoundrels and rouges of the night about. Alex walks away from door, then ducks into the bushes where the others are hiding. They put on their maskies and follow Alex round to the rear of the house.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Hi, hi, hi there, at last we meet.

turns.speaker: CATLADY
turns.text: What the bloody hell d'you think you're doing?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Our brief govereet thru the letter hole was not, shall we say, satisfactory, yes?

turns.speaker: CATLADY
turns.text: Now listen here, you little bastard, just you turn around and walk out of here the same way as you came in. Alex eyes a giant white, fibreglass phallic sculpture on the table beside him.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Naughty, naughty, naughty, you filthy old soomaka.

turns.speaker: CATLADY
turns.text: No! No! Don't touch it. That's a very important work of art. What the bloody hell do you want?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You see, madam, I am part of an international student's contest to see who can get the most points for selling magazines.

turns.speaker: CATLADY
turns.text: Cut the shit, sonny, and get out of here before you get yourself in some very serious trouble. He rocks the giant phallus which has a special weight swinging inside causing it to swing up and down an eccentric motion.

turns.speaker: DOLIN
turns.text: So this is the young man?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: How do you do, sir?

turns.speaker: DOLIN
turns.text: Hullo.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Missus. Very pleased to meet you.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Very kind of you, sir. Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: DOLIN
turns.text: I understand that you had a rather unfortunate encounter with the Police tonight.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, sir. I suppose you might call it that, sir.

turns.speaker: DOLIN
turns.text: Hahaha, and how are you feeling now?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Much better, thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: DOLIN
turns.text: Feel like talking to us. Answering a few questions?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Fine, sir, fine.

turns.speaker: DOLIN
turns.text: Well, as I've said, we've heard about you. We are interested in your case. We want to help you.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Thank you very much, sir.

turns.speaker: DOLIN
turns.text: But first we'd like to find out a few things about you.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What would you like to know, sir?

turns.speaker: DOLIN
turns.text: Well, shall we get down to it?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, sir. Rubinstein takes out a notebook.

turns.speaker: EM
turns.text: It's past eight, Alex, you don't want to be late for school, son.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Bit of pain in the gulliver, Mum. Leave us be and I'll try to sleep it off... then I'll be as right as dodgers for this after.

turns.speaker: EM
turns.text: You've not been to school all week, son.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I've got to rest, Mum... got to get fit, otherwise I'm liable to miss a lot more school.

turns.speaker: EM
turns.text: Eeee... I'll put your breakfast in the oven. I've got to be off myself now.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Alright, Mum... have a nice day at the factory.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Hi. Hi. Hi, there my Pee and Em. All three look up startled.

turns.speaker: EM
turns.text: Alex.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Hullo love, how are you?  Nice to see you, Dad.

turns.speaker: EM
turns.text: Why didn't you let us know what was happening, son?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Sorry, Em, I wanted it to be like... a big surprise for you and pee.

turns.speaker: DELTOID
turns.text: Ah, Alex boy, awake at last, yes? I met your mother on the way to work, yes? She gave me the key. She said something about a pain somewhere... hence not at school , yes?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: A rather intolerable pain in the head, brother, sir. I think it should be clear by this afterlunch.

turns.speaker: DELTOID
turns.text: Oh, or certainly by this evening, yes? The evening's a great time, isn't it, Alex boy?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: A cup of the old chai, sir?

turns.speaker: DELTOID
turns.text: No time, no time, yes. Sit, sit, sit. Alex sits next to him.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: To what do I owe this extreme pleasure, sir? Anything wrong, sir? Deltoid "playfully" grabs Alex's hair.

turns.speaker: DELTOID
turns.text: Wrong? Why should you think of anything being wrong, have you been doing something you shouldn't. Yes? He shakes Alex's hair.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Just a manner of speech, sir.

turns.speaker: DELTOID
turns.text: Well, yes, it's just a manner of speech from your Post Corrective Advisor to you that you watch out, little Alex. He puts his arm round Alex's shoulder.

turns.speaker: DELTOID
turns.text: Because next time it's going to be the barry place and all my work ruined. If you've no respect for your horrible self, you at least might have some for me who'se sweated over you. He slaps Alex on the knee.

turns.speaker: DELTOID
turns.text: A big black mark I tell you for every one we don't reclaim. A confession of failure for every one of you who ends up in the stripy hole.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I've been doing nothing I shouldn't, sir. The millicents have nothing on me, brother, sir, I mean. Deltoid pulls Alex down on the bed.

turns.speaker: DELTOID
turns.text: Cut out all this clever talk about milicents. Just because the Police haven't picked you up lately doesn't, as you very well know, mean that you've not been up to some nastiness. There was a bit of a nastiness last night, yes. Some very extreme nastiness, yes. A few of a certain Billyboy's friends were ambluenced off late last night, yes. Your name was mentioned, the word's got thru to me by the usual channels. Certain friends of yours were named also. Oh, nobody can prove anything about anybody as usual, but I'm warning you, little Alex, being a good friend to you as always, the one man in this sore and sick community who wants to save you from yourself. Deltoid makes a grab for Alex's joint but finds his hand instead. Alex laughs. Derisively and rises. Deltoid distractedly reaches for a glass of water on the night table, and fails to notice a set of false teeth soaking in them. He drinks from the glass. The clink of the teeth sounding like ice-cubes.

turns.speaker: DELTOID
turns.text: What gets into you all? We study the problem. We've been studying it for damn well near a century, yes, but we get no further with our studies. You've got a good home here, good loving parents, you've got not too bad of a brain. Is it some devil that crawls inside of you?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Nobody's got anything on me, brother, sir. I've been out of the rookers of the milicents for a long time now.

turns.speaker: DELTOID
turns.text: That's just worries me. A bit too long to long to be reasonable. You're about due now by my reckoning, that's why I'm warning you, little Alex, to keep your handsome young proboscis out of the dirt. Do I make myself clear?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: As an unmuddied lake, sir. Clear as an azure sky of deepest summer. You can rely on me, sir. Deltoid drinks again but this time sees the teeth in the glass. He groans and retches.

turns.speaker: DELTOID
turns.text: You are now a murderer, little Alex. A murderer, yes.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Not true, sir. It was only a slight tolchock. She was breathing, I swear it.

turns.speaker: DELTOID
turns.text: I've just come back from the hospital. Your victim has died.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You try to frighten me, sir, admit so, sir. This is some new form of torture. Say it, brother, sir.

turns.speaker: DELTOID
turns.text: It will be your own torture. I hope to God it will torture you to madness.

turns.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
turns.text: The newspapers mentioned that in addition to your being conditioned against acts of sex and violence, you've inadvertently been conditioned against music.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Well, er, I think that was something that they hadn't planned for, you see, Missus, I'm very fond of music and always have been, especially Beethoven, Ludwig van... Beethoven. B... E... E... He leans over and looks at her writing in notebook.

turns.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
turns.text: It's alright, thank you.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: And it just so happened that while they were showing me a particularly bad film, of like a concentration camp, the background music was playing Beethoven.

turns.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
turns.text: So now you have the same reaction to music as you do to sex and violence?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Oh well, it's... it's not all music you see, Missus. It's just the 9th.

turns.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
turns.text: You mean Beethoven's 9th Symphony?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: That's right. Er... I can't listen to the 9th any more at all. When I hear the 9th, I get like this funny feeling.

turns.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
turns.text: When you say this funny feeling, you mean the state of mind brought on by the treatment they gave you?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: That is correct, sir. And then all I can think about is like trying to snuff it.

turns.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Snuff it, sir... um... death, I mean, missus... Er... I just want to die peacefully like with no... pain.

turns.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
turns.text: Do you feel that way now?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Um... oh no, sir, not exactly, I still feel very miserable, very much down in spirits.

turns.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
turns.text: Do you still feel suicidal?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Um... well, put it this way... I feel very low in myself. I can't see much in the future, and I feel that any second something terrible is going to happen to me. He pitches forward, face into the plate of spaghetti.

turns.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
turns.text: Well done, Frank. Julian, get the car, will you please?

turns.speaker: GEORGIE
turns.text: We got worried. There we were waiting and drinking away at the old knify Moloko and you had not turned up and we thought you might have been like offended by something or other, so around we come to your abode.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Appy polly loggies. I had something of a pain in the gulliver so had to sleep. I was not awakened when I gave orders for awakening.

turns.speaker: GEORGIE
turns.text: All right, no more picking on Dim, brother. That's part of the new way.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: New way? What's this about a new way? There's been some very large talk behind my sleeping back, and no error. Let me hear more.

turns.speaker: GEORGIE
turns.text: Well, we go round shop crasting and the like, coming out with a pitiful rookerful of money each.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: And what will you do with the big, big, money? Have you not everything you need? If you need a motor-car, you pluck it from the trees. If you need pretty polly, you take it.

turns.speaker: GEORGIE
turns.text: Brother, you think and talk sometimes like a little child. Tonight we pull a mansize crast.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Good. Real horrorshow. Initiative comes to them as waits. I've taught you much, my little droogies. Now tell me what you have in mind, Georgie Boy.

turns.speaker: GEORGIE
turns.text: Oh, the old moloko-plus first, would you not say

turns.speaker: GEORGIE
turns.text: Not tonight - not this nochy.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Come, come, come, Georgie Boy. You're a big strong chelloveck like us all. We're not little children, are we, Georgie Boy? What, then, didst thou in thy mind have? Confrontation. Georgie backs down.

turns.speaker: GEORGIE
turns.text: It's this Health Farm. A bit out of the town. Isolated. It's owned by this like very rich ptitsa who lives there with her cats. The place is shut down for a week and she's completely on her own, and it's full up with like gold and silver and like jewels.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Tell me more, Georgie Boy.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Who said that?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I did, sir.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: What crime did you commit.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: The accidental killing of a person, sir.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Thank you very much for this chance, sir.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Let's hope you make the most of it, my boy.
